FEW VETERANS BACK
FOR FOOTBALL TEAM
Kegan, Strader, Lyons, Houston,
Caplan Return
FIRST GAME SATURDAY
Jays Play Richmond This
Week
Facing the task of building a new
team around Captain Sttader, center, Caplan and Lyons, back field
men, and Houston and Kegan," on
end and guard, respectively, the
coaches of the Hopkins eleven are
slowly rounding a team into shape.
The Black and Blue team is well
equipped in the coaching department. Headed by Dr. Ray Van Orman, George Darley, Tom Magill,
and 'Dave Kaufman are putting
those seeking berths through the
paces. Van Orman and Darley are
coaching the backs and. ends, while
Magill and Kaufman are shaping up
the candidates for berths in the forward wall.
Good Backs
The backfield question is one
which worries the coaches least, four
capable backs having been placed.
Besides Lyons and Caplan, Harry
Love and Ed Besore have been
showing up unusually well in the
backfield. In scrimmages, Love has
been taking care of the full back
position, Pindell having left that
berth open from last year. Alfif6re
has been filling Lawrence's/Pace at
half back.
Their positions are not by any
means secure, however, as several
other ocandidates are showing up
well. Bledsoe, Gibson, Devereux,
Hershey, and Morrison are those
...• • ,

Entered as second-class matter December 3, 1909, at the Postoffice in
Baltimore, Md., under Act of Congress November 3, 1879.
Published semi-weekly from October to June by the students of Johns
Hopkins University.
Business communications should be addressed to the BUSINESS MANAGER,
Johns Hopkins University. All articles should be sent to the MANAGING
EDITOR; other communications to the EDITOR-IN-CHIEF.

Little time is wasted at' Union
College in giving frosh their baptism of fire. By last Monday three
organized battles were held and several more informal skirmishes were
seen, The yearlings suffered heavy
losses until they were organized,
but in the several rushes the youngsters captured all but one.

CAMPBELL
FORDYa E. C.
HOPKNS ALUMNUS

CALL

IN ARCOLLEGIATE
NEWS

A very enjoyable evening was
spent on the Lehigh campu‘ last
Wednesday evening When the frosh
had their annual pajama parade.
Rain, wind, and sophomores enlivened the program that wa.rwitnessed by the students and townfolk of
Bethlahem.
The freshmen clad only in informal evening wear were made to carry candles, which they had to keep
lit at any cost. Kowtowing in the
mud, songs and dances, and a final
additional drenching by a garden
hos!, completed the festivities.
* * '*
The University of Maryland, it
seems, places a world of confidence
in the abilities of their alumni. It
has been recently announced that a
member of the class of '28, formerly
a student in the school of home economics, has been appointed .a dietician in the college dining hall, '

Minneapolis, Minn.
April 30, 1928
Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Dear Sirs:
Two years ago last winter I went
into the Red Lake gold fields in
Canada. It was a tough trail from
Hudson, over 140 miles of snow and
ice. There were fourteen of us on the
trail going in, and frequently at night
when seated around a big camp fire,
some one would ask me for a pipeful
of Edgeworth. These Canadian bdys
sure like our Edgeworth.
In four weeks' time I ran out of
Edgeworth. I was glad to get 'most
any old tobacco.
One day, however,I dropped in to
Dad Brown's tent, a 72-year-old prospecfor, and seeing a can of Edgeworth
on an improvised table, bask there 150
miles from the "steel," I perked up at
once, saying, "Dad, I'm plum out of
tobacco—how:a chances for a pipeful?" "Help yourself," he said. So
pulling my heavy duty pipe from my
pocket, I loaded it with Edg wo th,
packing it in so tightly that I co n't
get the least bit of a draw.
I excused myself for a moment, and
stepped outside to remove about three
pipefuls to put in my pouch. Dad
stepped out, saying, "You're worse
than any Scotchman I ever saw."
Then I confessed. I told him what
happened to my Edgeworth—that I
was just dying for a smoke, and he
understood right away. He said,
"Boy, Edgeworth is mighty scarce in
these parts, but I reckon I can spare
what's left of that can. Help yourself."
You can just bet your last nickel
that I guarded this Edgeworth with
extreme care until I got back to the
"steel."
Yours very truly,
C. M.Bahr

FEW VETERANS BACK
FOR FOOTBALL TEAM
Kegan, Strader, Lyons, Houston,
Caplan Return
FIRST GAME SATURDAY
Jays Play Richmond This
Week
Facing the task of building a new
team around Captain Sttader, center, Caplan and Lyons, back field
men, and Houston and Kegan," on
end and guard, respectively, the
coaches of the Hopkins eleven are
slowly rounding a team into shape.
The Black and Blue team is well
equipped in the coaching department. Headed by Dr. Ray Van Orman, George Darley, Tom Magill,
and 'Dave Kaufman are putting
those seeking berths through the
paces. Van Orman and Darley are
coaching the backs and. ends, while
Magill and Kaufman are shaping up
the candidates for berths in the forward wall.
Good Backs
The backfield question is one
which worries the coaches least, four
capable backs having been placed.
Besides Lyons and Caplan, Harry
Love and Ed Besore have been
showing up unusually well in the
backfield. In scrimmages, Love has
been taking care of the full back
position, Pindell having left that
berth open from last year. Alfif6re
has been filling Lawrence's/Pace at
half back.
Their positions are not by any
means secure, however, as several
other ocandidates are showing up
well. Bledsoe, Gibson, Devereux,
Hershey, and Morrison are those
...• • ,

Little time is wasted at' Union
College in giving frosh their baptism of fire. By last Monday three
organized battles were held and several more informal skirmishes were
seen, The yearlings suffered heavy
losses until they were organized,
but in the several rushes the youngsters captured all but one.

CAMPBELL
FORDYa E. C.
HOPKNS ALUMNUS

CALL

IN ARCOLLEGIATE
NEWS

A very enjoyable evening was
spent on the Lehigh campu‘ last
Wednesday evening When the frosh
had their annual pajama parade.
Rain, wind, and sophomores enlivened the program that wa.rwitnessed by the students and townfolk of
Bethlahem.
The freshmen clad only in informal evening wear were made to carry candles, which they had to keep
lit at any cost. Kowtowing in the
mud, songs and dances, and a final
additional drenching by a garden
hos!, completed the festivities.
* * '*
The University of Maryland, it
seems, places a world of confidence
in the abilities of their alumni. It
has been recently announced that a
member of the class of '28, formerly
a student in the school of home economics, has been appointed .a dietician in the college dining hall, '

Minneapolis, Minn.
April 30, 1928
Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Dear Sirs:
Two years ago last winter I went
into the Red Lake gold fields in
Canada. It was a tough trail from
Hudson, over 140 miles of snow and
ice. There were fourteen of us on the
trail going in, and frequently at night
when seated around a big camp fire,
some one would ask me for a pipeful
of Edgeworth. These Canadian bdys
sure like our Edgeworth.
In four weeks' time I ran out of
Edgeworth. I was glad to get 'most
any old tobacco.
One day, however,I dropped in to
Dad Brown's tent, a 72-year-old prospecfor, and seeing a can of Edgeworth
on an improvised table, bask there 150
miles from the "steel," I perked up at
once, saying, "Dad, I'm plum out of
tobacco—how:a chances for a pipeful?" "Help yourself," he said. So
pulling my heavy duty pipe from my
pocket, I loaded it with Edg wo th,
packing it in so tightly that I co n't
get the least bit of a draw.
I excused myself for a moment, and
stepped outside to remove about three
pipefuls to put in my pouch. Dad
stepped out, saying, "You're worse
than any Scotchman I ever saw."
Then I confessed. I told him what
happened to my Edgeworth—that I
was just dying for a smoke, and he
understood right away. He said,
"Boy, Edgeworth is mighty scarce in
these parts, but I reckon I can spare
what's left of that can. Help yourself."
You can just bet your last nickel
that I guarded this Edgeworth with
extreme care until I got back to the
"steel."
Yours very truly,
C. M.Bahr
